In general, MPC can be implemented through three different frameworks: 1) Secret Sharing (SS) [193, 194], 2) Oblivious Transfer (OT) [195, 196], and 3) Threshold Homomorphic Encryption (THE) [197, 198]. From a certain point of view, both oblivious transfer protocols and threshold homomorphic encryption schemes use the idea of secret sharing. This might be why secret sharing is widely regarded as the core of MPC. In the rest of this section, we will introduce secret sharing and oblivious transfer.

a) Secret sharing (SS) hides a secret value by splitting it into random parts and distributing these parts (a.k.a. shares) to different parties, so that each party has only one share and thus only one piece of the secret [199, 193]. Every secret sharing protocol consists of:

    A security condition. Depending on the specific secret sharing schemes used, all or a known threshold of shares are needed to reconstruct the original secret value [200, 193]. For example, Shamir’s Secret Sharing is constructed based on polynomial equations and provides information-theoretical security, and it is also efficient using matrix calculation speedup [193].

For arithmetic secret sharing, consider that a party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} wants to share a secret S𝑆S among n𝑛n parties {Pi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑃𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{P_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} in a finite field Fqsubscript𝐹𝑞F_{q}. We denote the shared S𝑆S as ⟨S⟩={si}i=1ndelimited-⟨⟩𝑆superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖1𝑛\langle S\rangle=\{s_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}.

To conduct secure addition, each party locally carries out the arithmetic addition operation one two secret shares. The secure multiplication can be performed via Beaver triples [201], which can be generated in an offline phase.

b) Oblivious transfer (OT) is a two-party computation protocol proposed by Rabin in 1981 [202]. Here, we define 1-out-of-n OT:

Definition A.1.

1-out-of-n Oblivious Transfer: Suppose Party A has a list (x1,…,xn)subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛(x_{1},...,x_{n}) as the input, Party B has i∈1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i\in{1,...,n} as the input. 1-out-of-n Oblivious Transfer is an MPC protocol where A learns FA=0subscript𝐹𝐴0F_{A}=0 and B learns FB=xisubscript𝐹𝐵subscript𝑥𝑖F_{B}=x_{i}, that is,

  1. 1.

    A learns nothing about i𝑖i.

  2. 2.

    B learns nothing else but xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}.

When n=2𝑛2n=2, we get 1-out-of-2 OT which has the following property: 1-out-of-2 OT is universal for 2-party MPC [203]. That is, one can conduct any 2-party MPC given a 1-out-of-2 OT protocol.

There are many constructions of OT such as Bellare-Micali’s [204], Naor-Pinka’s [205] and Hazay-Lindell’s [206] approaches. The construction of OT requires public-key type of assumptions (e.g., discrete log assumption) [207], which is computational costly. For efficiency, Beaver [208] proposed to extend OT by first generating a few seed OTs based on public-key cryptography, which can then be extended to any number of OTs using symmetric-key cryptosystems only. OT extension is now widely applied in MPC protocols [209, 210, 196] to improve efficiency.

Yao’s Garbled Circuit (GC) [192] is an OT-based secure 2-party computation protocol that can evaluate any function. The key idea of Yao’s GC is to decompose the computational circuits (we can use circuits (AND, OR, XOR) to compute any arithmetic operation) into generation and evaluation stages.

A-2 Homomorphic Encryption

Homomorphic encryption (HE) is a cryptographic scheme that enables homomorphic operations on encrypted data without decryption. The concept of HE was initially introduced by Rivest et al. [211] in 1978 to perform computation over ciphertext. Since then, researchers has made may attempts to design such homomorphic schemes.

An HE scheme ℋℋ\mathcal{H} is an encryption scheme that allows certain algebraic operations to be carried out on the encrypted content, by applying an efficient operation to the corresponding ciphertext without knowing the decryption key.

Definition A.2.

(Homomorphic Encryption) An HE scheme ℋℋ\mathcal{H} consists of the following poly-time algorithms:

ℋ={K​e​y​G​e​n,E​n​c,D​e​c,E​v​a​l}ℋ𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐷𝑒𝑐𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙\mathcal{H}=\{KeyGen,Enc,Dec,Eval\} (1)

where

  • -

    K​e​y​G​e​n𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛KeyGen: Key generation. A cryptographic generator g𝑔g is taken as the input. For asymmetric HE, a pair of keys {p​k,s​k}=K​e​y​G​e​n​(g)𝑝𝑘𝑠𝑘𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑔\{pk,sk\}=KeyGen(g) are generated, where p​k𝑝𝑘pk is the public key for encryption and s​k𝑠𝑘sk is the secret key for decryption. For symmetric HE, only a secret key s​k=K​e​y​G​e​n​(g)𝑠𝑘𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑔sk=KeyGen(g) is generated.

  • -

    E​n​c𝐸𝑛𝑐Enc: Encryption. For asymmetric HE, an encryption scheme takes the public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and the plaintext m𝑚m as the input, and generates the ciphertext c=E​n​cp​k​(m)𝑐𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝𝑘𝑚c=Enc_{pk}(m) as the output. For symmetric HE, an HE scheme takes the secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and the plaintext m𝑚m, and generates ciphertext c=E​n​cs​k​(m)𝑐𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑠𝑘𝑚c=Enc_{sk}(m).

  • -

    D​e​c𝐷𝑒𝑐Dec: Decryption. Given the secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and the ciphertext c𝑐c, the corresponding plaintext m=D​e​cs​k​(c)𝑚𝐷𝑒subscript𝑐𝑠𝑘𝑐m=Dec_{sk}(c).

  • -

    E​v​a​l𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙Eval: Evaluation. The function E​v​a​l𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙Eval takes the ciphertexts c,c′𝑐superscript𝑐′c,c^{\prime} as the input, and outputs a ciphertext corresponding to a functioned plaintext.

Let E​n​cp​k​(⋅)𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝𝑘⋅Enc_{pk}(\cdot) denote the encryption function with p​k𝑝𝑘pk as the encryption key. Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} denote the plaintext space and 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} denote the ciphertext space. A secure cryptosystem is called homomorphic if it satisfies the following condition: ∀m1,m2∈ℳ,E​n​cp​k​(m1⊙ℳm2)←E​n​cp​k​(m1)⊙𝒞E​n​cp​k​(m2)formulae-sequencefor-allsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2ℳ←𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝𝑘subscriptdirect-productℳsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑚2subscriptdirect-product𝒞𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝𝑘subscript𝑚1𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝𝑘subscript𝑚2\forall m_{1},m_{2}\in\mathcal{M},\;\;Enc_{pk}(m_{1}\odot_{\mathcal{M}}m_{2})\leftarrow Enc_{pk}(m_{1})\odot_{\mathcal{C}}Enc_{pk}(m_{2}) for some operators ⊙ℳsubscriptdirect-productℳ\odot_{\mathcal{M}} in ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and ⊙𝒞subscriptdirect-product𝒞\odot_{\mathcal{C}} in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, where ←←\leftarrow indicates the left-hand side term is equal to or can be directly computed from the right-hand side term without any intermediate decryption.

There are three types of HE schemes:

  • •

    Partially Homomorphic Encryption (PHE) supports the evaluation of functionality with one type algebraic operation (e.g. addition).

  • •

    Somewhat Homomorphic Encryption (SHE) schemes can evaluate two types of algebraic operations, but only for a subset of functionality.

  • •

    Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) supports the evaluation of arbitrary functionality composed of multiple types of algebraic operations.

In general, for HE schemes, the computational complexity increases as the functionality grows. Interested readers can refer to [212] and [213] for more details regarding different classes of HE schemes.

The Goldwasser–Micali cryptosystem [214] is a PHE scheme that enables addition modulo 2 operation over ciphertext. The Paillier cryptosystem [215] is a PHE scheme that allows additive operations over ciphertext. It has been widely applied to various PPML researches. Gentry [216] proposed the first FHE scheme that supports both additive and multiplicative operations for unlimited number of times. Recently, Cheon, Kim, Kim and Song (CKKS) [32] proposed an approximate FHE scheme that supports a special kind of fixed-point arithmetic. The CKKS scheme is the most efficient approach for evaluating polynomial approximations, and is the preferred approach for implementing PPML applications.

A-3 Differential Privacy

Differential Privacy (DP) [217] was initially developed to facilitate secure analysis over privacy-sensitive data. The key idea of DP is to protect membership-privacy by confusing the adversary when it tries to query individual information so that adversaries cannot distinguish individual-level sensitivity from the query results.

DP provides an information-theoretic security guarantee that the output of a function is insensitive to any particular record in the dataset. Therefore, DP can be used to resist the membership inference attack. The (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy is defined as follows:

Definition A.3.

(ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy. A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} preserves (ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if given any two datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differing by only one record, and for all S⊂R​a​n​g​e​(ℳ)𝑆𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑔𝑒ℳS\subset Range(\mathcal{M}),

P​r​[ℳ​(d)∈S]≤exp​(ϵ)​P​r​[ℳ​(D′)∈S]+δ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳ𝑑𝑆expitalic-ϵ𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆𝛿Pr[\mathcal{M}(d)\in S]\leq\text{exp}(\epsilon)Pr[\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S]+\delta

where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is the privacy budget and δ𝛿\delta is the failure probability.

When δ=0𝛿0\delta=0, we achieve a stronger notion named ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy. The privacy loss is defined as l​n​P​r​[ℳ​(D)∈S]P​r​[ℳ​(D′)∈S]𝑙𝑛𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳ𝐷𝑆𝑃𝑟delimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆ln\frac{Pr[\mathcal{M}(D)\in S]}{Pr[\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S]} , where l​n𝑙𝑛ln denotes natural logarithm.

The approaches to design DP algorithms can be categorized into two types. One is the addition of noise according to the sensitivity of a function [217]. The other is choosing noise according to an exponential distribution on discrete values [218].

The sensitivity of a real-valued function expresses the maximum possible change in its value due to the addition or removal of a single sample:

Definition A.4.

(Sensitivity) For two datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} differing by only one record, and a function ℳ:𝒟→ℛd:ℳ→𝒟superscriptℛ𝑑\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}^{d} over an arbitrary domain, the sensitivity of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the maximum change in the output of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} over all possible inputs:

Δ​ℳ=maxD,D′⁡∥ℳ​(D)−ℳ​(D′)∥Δℳsubscript𝐷superscript𝐷′ℳ𝐷ℳsuperscript𝐷′\Delta\mathcal{M}=\max\limits_{D,D^{\prime}}\;\lVert{\mathcal{M}(D)-\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})}\rVert (2)

where ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\lVert\cdot\rVert is a norm of the vector. The l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}-sensitivity or the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-sensitivity is defined when the l1subscript𝑙1l_{1}-norm or l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-norm is applied, respectively.

We denote the Laplace distribution with parameter b𝑏b as L​a​p​(b)𝐿𝑎𝑝𝑏Lap(b). L​a​p​(b)𝐿𝑎𝑝𝑏Lap(b) has a probability density function P​(z|b)=12​b​e​x​p​(−|z|/b)𝑃conditional𝑧𝑏12𝑏𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑧𝑏P(z|b)=\frac{1}{2b}exp(-|z|/b). Given a function ℳℳ\mathcal{M} with sensitivity Δ​ℳΔℳ\Delta\mathcal{M}, the addition of noise drawn from a calibrated Laplace distribution L​a​p​(Δ​ℳ/ϵ)𝐿𝑎𝑝Δℳitalic-ϵLap(\Delta\mathcal{M}/\epsilon) maintains ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy [217]:

Theorem A.5.

(Laplace mechanism). Given a function ℳ:𝒟→ℛd:ℳ→𝒟superscriptℛd\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}^{d} over an arbitrary domain DDD, for any input XXX, the function:

ℳ​(X)+L​a​p​(Δ​ℳϵ)dℳ𝑋𝐿𝑎𝑝superscriptΔℳitalic-ϵ𝑑\mathcal{M}(X)+Lap(\frac{\Delta\mathcal{M}}{\epsilon})^{d} (3)

provides ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy.

The ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy can also be achieved by adding independently generated Laplace noise from distribution L​a​p​(Δ​ℳ/ϵ)𝐿𝑎𝑝Δℳitalic-ϵLap(\Delta\mathcal{M}/\epsilon) to each of the d𝑑d output terms. Moreover, changing Laplace noise to Gaussian or binomial noise, and scale to the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-sensitivity of the function, sometimes yields better accuracy but only ensures weaker DP [219, 220].

The exponential mechanism [218] can achieve DP on discrete values. The exponential mechanism is given a quality function q𝑞q that scores outcomes of a calculation, where higher scores are better. For a given database and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon parameter, the quality function induces a probability distribution over the output domain, from which the exponential mechanism samples the outcome. This probability distribution favors high-scoring outcomes, while ensuring ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy.

Theorem A.6.

(Exponential mechanism). Let q:(𝒟n×ℛ)→ℝ:q→superscript𝒟nℛℝq:(\mathcal{D}^{n}\times\mathcal{R})\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a quality function, which given a dataset d∈𝒟ndsuperscript𝒟nd\in\mathcal{D}^{n}, assigns a score to each outcome r∈ℛrℛr\in\mathcal{R}. For any two datasets DDD and D′superscriptD′D^{\prime} differing by only one record, let S(q)=maxr,D,D′∥q(D,r)−q(D′,r)∥1S(q)=\max\limits_{r,D,D^{\prime}}\lVert q(D,r)-q(D^{\prime},r)\rVert_{1}. Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} be a mechanism for choosing an outcome r∈ℛrℛr\in\mathcal{R} given a dataset instance d∈DndsuperscriptDnd\in D^{n}. Then, the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, defined as

ℳ​(d,q)={return r with prob.∝exp⁡(ϵ​q​(d,r)2​S​(q))}ℳ𝑑𝑞proportional-toreturn r with prob.italic-ϵ𝑞𝑑𝑟2𝑆𝑞\mathcal{M}(d,q)=\left\{\text{return $r$ with prob.}\propto\exp\left(\frac{\epsilon q(d,r)}{2S(q)}\right)\right\} (4)

provides ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-differential privacy.

According to how and where the noise perturbation is applied, the DP algorithms can be categorized into four types as follows:

  1. 1.

    Input perturbation: The noise is added to the training data.

  2. 2.

    Objective perturbation: The noise is added to the objective function of the learning algorithms.

  3. 3.

    Algorithm perturbation: The noise is added to the intermediate values such as gradients in iterative algorithms.

  4. 4.

    Output perturbation: The noise is added to the output parameters after training.

Differential privacy only aims to protect membership-privacy that one adversary can not determine if a certain instance is inside the dataset. However, the statistics of the dataset can still be revealed, which could be sensitive in some cases, such as financial data, medical data and other commercial and health applications. Moreover, DP faces a trade-off between utility and privacy as it introduces noises to results. It is shown that current DP mechanisms in ML rarely provide practical privacy-utility trade-offs: settings that provide little accuracy loss can hardly provide strong privacy protection, while the settings that provide strong privacy result in large accuracy loss. Readers who are interested in differential privacy can refer to the tutorial given by [221].

A-4 Trusted Execution Environment

As an attempt to guarantee data privacy while compromising less efficiency and utility, the Trusted Execution Environment (TEE), a hardware-based private data analysis technique, attracts increasing attention in the PPML community [222, 223, 224].

Definition A.7.

A TEE is a tamper-resistant processing environment that guarantees the authenticity of the code executed, the integrity of the runtime states, and the confidentiality of its code, data, and runtime states stored on persistent memory. It runs on a separation kernel which guarantees spatial and temporal separation, control of information flow and fault isolation.

Representative implementations include Intel’s SGX technology, AMD’s SEV technology, and ARM’s TrustZone technology. Fan and Hamed [223] explored the use of TrustZone in edge devices to conduct efficient and private FL. The local model training process is conducted in the TEE of client devices to prevent clients from inferring information from gradients present in the global model or conducting causative attacks. The server encrypts the model after model aggregation and sends it to the clients. The model is decrypted inside the TEE for training, in which the client can not learn information about the model. After local training, the trusted application encrypts the model before sending it outside the TrustZone and back to the server. Therefore, all clients collaboratively train the model without knowing its plaintext. Chen et al. [224] studied the privacy-preserving FL with TEE via SGX. Local model training and severe model aggregation are conducted in secure enclaves for privacy preservation and training process integrity. Apart from protecting the model against clients by conducting FL in TEEs of edge devices and encrypting models, clients can also encrypt and send private data to TEE in a server. The server then decrypts data inside TEE and trains a global model over data contributed by all the clients.

Appendix B Knowledge Distillation

Three forms of knowledge can be leveraged to transfer knowledge from the teacher model to the student model: response-based knowledge, feature-based knowledge, and relation-based knowledge. We introduce different categories of knowledge as follows.

a) Response-based knowledge refers to the logits z𝑧z, which are the outputs of a deep model’s last fully connected layer. The response-based knowledge distillation directly mimics the final prediction of the teacher model and has been widely used in Hetero-FTL. In response-based knowledge distillation, soft targets [162] are introduced to improve knowledge transfer as they contain the informative dark knowledge from the teacher model. Soft targets are the probabilities that the input belongs to the class and can be estimated by a softmax function as

p​(zi,T)=e​x​p​(zi/T)∑je​x​p​(zj)/T,𝑝subscript𝑧𝑖𝑇𝑒𝑥𝑝subscript𝑧𝑖𝑇subscript𝑗𝑒𝑥𝑝subscript𝑧𝑗𝑇p(z_{i},T)=\frac{exp(z_{i}/T)}{\sum_{j}exp(z_{j})/T},

where zisubscript𝑧𝑖z_{i} is the logit for the i𝑖i-th class, and T𝑇T is a temperature factor that controls the importance of each soft target. The distillation loss is the divergence of the soft targets of teacher and student, which can be formulated as

ℒR​e​s=T2​ℒd​i​v​(p​(zt,T),p​(zs,T)),subscriptℒ𝑅𝑒𝑠superscript𝑇2subscriptℒ𝑑𝑖𝑣𝑝subscript𝑧𝑡𝑇𝑝subscript𝑧𝑠𝑇\mathcal{L}_{Res}=T^{2}\mathcal{L}_{div}(p(z_{t},T),p(z_{s},T)),

where ℒd​i​vsubscriptℒ𝑑𝑖𝑣\mathcal{L}_{div} denotes that divergence loss of soft targets. Generally, ℒd​i​vsubscriptℒ𝑑𝑖𝑣\mathcal{L}_{div} often employs Kullback-Leibler(KL) divergence loss. In vanilla knowledge distillation [162], the student model is trained by the distillation loss and the cross entropy loss ℒC​E​(y,p​(zs,T=1))subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝑦𝑝subscript𝑧𝑠𝑇1\mathcal{L}_{CE}(y,p(z_{s},T=1)) between the ground truth labels and the soft logits of the student model.

b) Feature-based knowledge distillation employs the output of intermediate layers to replace the logits used in response-based knowledge. The feature activations of the teacher and the student are directly matched to distillation loss. Therefore, the teacher and the student models first project the features to a common latent space. Then, a distillation loss is employed to minimize the distance of the two feature representations from the teacher and the student of the same instance in the latent space. Zhu et al. [144] propose to use a generative network to learn feature representations to transfer knowledge between parties in FL.

c) Relation-based knowledge explores the distance between different instances or layers in the same model as knowledge to train the student model. The distillation loss is based on relations of feature representations [225] or instance[226, 227, 228]. Yim et al. [225] transfer knowledge to the student model via the Gram matrix between two layers. The mutual relations of instances are also leveraged as knowledge [226, 228]. Park et al. [228] transfer knowledge from instance relations by proposing a relational knowledge distillation scheme. Passalis et al. [227] use feature representations to model the instance-wise relations as probabilistic distribution.
